reasoning: The King questions the Duchess’s Cook as a witness.
support_text: The next witness was the Duchess's cook. 'Give your evidence,' said the King. 'Shan't,' said the cook.

reasoning: The Cook answers about the tarts and the Dormouse pipes up behind her.
support_text: 'Pepper, mostly,' said the cook. 'Treacle,' said a sleepy voice behind her.

reasoning: The Queen orders the Dormouse seized and punished.
support_text: 'Collar that Dormouse,' the Queen shrieked out. 'Behead that Dormouse!'

reasoning: Alice observes the White Rabbit managing the witness list and later calling her name.
support_text: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list... the White Rabbit read out... the name Alice!

reasoning: The King directly questions Alice during the trial.
support_text: "What do you know about this business?" the King said to Alice.

reasoning: Alice notices and rights Bill the Lizard after putting him head downwards.
support_text: ...she had put the Lizard in head downwards... She soon got it out again, and put it right;

reasoning: The White Rabbit corrects the King and addresses him as Your Majesty.
support_text: ...the White Rabbit interrupted: "Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,"

reasoning: The White Rabbit answers the Queen’s question about the paper.
support_text: "What's in it?" said the Queen. "I haven't opened it yet," said the White Rabbit...

reasoning: The Knave pleads to the King that he did not write the verses and is later questioned by him.
support_text: "Please your Majesty," said the Knave, "I didn't write it..."

reasoning: The Queen declares the Knave guilty during the trial.
support_text: "That proves his guilt," said the Queen.

reasoning: The King speaks to the Queen about fits and she answers.
support_text: "...you never had fits, my dear, I think?" he said to the Queen. "Never!" said the Queen...

reasoning: The Queen throws an inkstand at Bill the Lizard.
support_text: "Never!" said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard...

reasoning: Alice defies the Queen and they argue in court.
support_text: "Stuff and nonsense!" said Alice... "Hold your tongue!" said the Queen.

reasoning: Alice wakes on the bank with her head in her sister’s lap and they speak.
support_text: "Wake up, Alice dear!" said her sister; "Why, what a long sleep you've had!"

reasoning: Her Sister dreams of the White Rabbit hurrying by.
support_text: ...the White Rabbit hurried by...

reasoning: Her Sister imagines the frightened Mouse splashing through the pool.
support_text: ...the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool...

reasoning: Her Sister hears the March Hare at his never-ending tea.
support_text: ...the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal...

reasoning: Her Sister hears the Queen’s shrill voice ordering executions.
support_text: ...the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution...

reasoning: Her Sister pictures the pig-baby sneezing on the Duchess’s knee.
support_text: ...the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess's knee...

reasoning: Her Sister hears the shriek of the Gryphon in her reverie.
support_text: ...the shriek of the Gryphon...

reasoning: Her Sister hears the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil (Bill the Lizard).
support_text: ...the squeaking of the Lizard's slate-pencil...

reasoning: Her Sister hears the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
support_text: ...the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
